title: Those Modern Pathologies
summary:
Key ideas
- Modern individualism reduces experiences and relationships to commodities and demands material end products to model laboring-for-others
- The Odyssey is a book for rich individualist aspirational Very Smart narcissists who want to outsource their ennobling hardships to the lower classes
- Aristotle's theory of virtue reduces perfect virtue to the comfortable neoliberal plateau of watching TV and ordering off Amazon Echo
- Catholicism reduces the human relationship with the Divine to literally consuming God in a top-down chain of standardized religion products
Key learnings
- Modern individualism, Catholicism, and Aristotle's theory of virtue are all modern pathologies
- The Odyssey is a book for rich individualist aspirational Very Smart narcissists
- Catholicism is the ultimate sign of our inability to deal with the world through anything other than a late capitalist lens
Key questions
- What other modern pathologies exist?
- What is the psychological profile of those who enjoy the Odyssey?
- How can we deal with the world without falling into the trap of modern pathologies?
